title: detail log/control of sync process
body:
i want to have a detailed log of which file has been synchronised why and when and by whom.

i had some strange behavior when testing owncloud.

on one client i chose a wrong base directory ( one level below ) so all files were duplicated on both sides. i interrupted that process and deleted the wrong files some time afterwards. but some other client must have copied them and they kept reappeating but i couldn't really find out from where they came. after having them deleted about twenty times they were finally gone.

then just some days ago all the files from a connected dropbox vanished. the dropbox itself has not been touched as far as i could see - there were no files missing there, so i guess it's a problem with the interface rather than that someone accidentally deleted the files.

just in these two case i would have been happy to be able to see from where the "commands" came. then i could have gone to the specific source of the problem and cleaned it up. but i just couldn't find out.

then it would be nice to be able to have a more transparent insight into the synchronisation process, not only from a diagnostic view but also being able to change it. unisons gui is an example here. i can choose which files not to transfer and to keep in a different state.

in a situation where something is going clearly wrong i would like to be able to stop the synchronisation and change the process. stopping is possible in the client. but i would like to know 1) what is going to happen further on and 2) be able to stop a specific synchronisation task. 3) i want to know who or what triggered the sync process.

i see that this is also a design question. in commercial software you don't have influence to these fine tuning aspects. that's one reason that i use free software: i can change the way things happen. but 1) for the majority it is a hindrance to have too many config options. and 2) if a system works you don't need finetuning.

but as far as i can see 1) owncloud is not yet in the state of being so stable that it runs as smoothly as dropbox or other commercial software and 2) i personnaly would like to be able to fiddle with the underlying process and not have it hidden like in modern cars where the engine is sealed in plastic.
